context: Tina makes $18.00 an hour.  If she works more than 8 hours per shift, she is eligible for overtime, which is paid by your hourly wage + 1/2 your hourly wage.
main-q: If she works 10 hours every day for 5 days, how much money does she make?
qa-pairs: How much does Tina make in an 8-hour shift?
She works 8 hours a day for $18 per hour so she makes 8*18 = $<<8*18=144.00>>144.00 per 8-hour shift.
How many hours of overtime does Tina get?
She works 10 hours a day and anything over 8 hours is eligible for overtime, so she gets 10-8 = <<10-8=2>>2 hours of overtime.
How much does Tina make in overtime?
Overtime is calculated as time and a half so and she makes $18/hour so her overtime pay is 18*.5 = $<<18*.5=9.00>>9.00.
How much does Tina make in overtime?
How much does Tina make in a week?
Her base pay is $144.00 per 8-hour shift and she works 5 days and makes 5 * $144 = $<<144*5=720.00>>720.00.
How much does Tina make in overtime?
Her overtime pay is $27.00 per hour and she works 2 hours of overtime per day and makes 27*2 = $<<27*2=54.00>>54.00 in overtime pay.

context: James creates a media empire.  He creates a movie for $2000.  Each DVD cost $6 to make.  He sells it for 2.5 times that much.  He sells 500 movies a day for 5 days a week.
main-q: How much profit does he make in 20 weeks?
qa-pairs: How much did each DVD cost?
He sold each DVD for 6*2.5=$<<6*2.5=15>>15.
How much profit does he make?
So he makes a profit of 15-6=$<<15-6=9>>9.
How much profit does he make in a day?
So each day he makes a profit of 9*500=$<<9*500=4500>>4500.
How much profit does he make in 5 days?
How much profit does he make in 20 weeks?
How much profit does he make after the cost of creating the movie?
Then after the cost of creating the movie he has a profit of 450,000-2000=$<<450000-2000=448000>>448,000.

context: In a truck, there are 26 pink hard hats, 15 green hard hats, and 24 yellow hard hats.  If Carl takes away 4 pink hard hats, and John takes away 6 pink hard hats and twice as many green hard hats as the number of pink hard hats that he removed, then calculate the total number of hard hats that remained in the truck.
qa-pairs: How many pink hard hats remained after Carl took away 4?
If there were 26 pink hard hats and Carl took away 4 pink hard hats, the number of pink hard hats that remained is 26-4 = <<26-4=22>>22.
How many pink hard hats remained after John took away 6?
John also took away 6 pink hard hats, leaving 22-6 = <<22-6=16>>16 pink hard hats in the truck.
How many green hard hats did John take away?
If John also took twice as many green hard hats as pink hard hats, he took 2*6 = <<6*2=12>>12 green hard hats.
How many green hard hats remained after John took away 12?
The total number of green hard hats that remained in the truck is 15-12 = <<15-12=3>>3.
How many hard hats remained in the truck after some are taken?
In the truck, after some are taken, there were 3 green hard hats + 16 pink hard hats = <<3+16=19>>19 hard hats in the truck.
How many hard hats remained in the truck?
Altogether, 19 green and pink hard hats + 24 yellow hards hats = <<19+24=43>>43 hard hats remained in the truck.

context: Mrs. Snyder used to spend 40% of her monthly income on rent and utilities. Her salary was recently increased by $600 so now her rent and utilities only amount to 25% of her monthly income.
main-q: How much was her previous monthly income?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let her previous monthly income be p.
How much was her previous monthly income?
The cost of her rent and utilities was 40% of p which is (40/100)*p = 2p/5.
How much was her previous monthly income?
Her income was increased by $600 so it is now p+$600.
How much was her previous monthly income?
The cost of her rent and utilities now amount to 25% of (p+$600) which is (25/100)*(p+$600) = (p+$600)/4.
How much was her previous monthly income?
Equating both expressions for cost of rent and utilities: 2p/5 = (p+$600)/4.
How much was her previous monthly income?
Multiplying both sides of the equation by 20 gives 8p = 5p+$3000.

context: A concert ticket costs $40. Mr. Benson bought 12 tickets and received a 5% discount for every ticket bought that exceeds 10. How much did Mr.
main-q: Benson pay in all?
qa-pairs: How many tickets did Mr. Benson buy?
Mr. Benson had a 5% discount for each of the 12 - 10 = <<12-10=2>>2 tickets.
How much did those two tickets cost?
So, those two tickets had a $40 x 5/100 = $<<40*5/100=2>>2 discount each.
How much did each ticket cost?
Hence, each ticket cost $40 - $2 = $<<40-2=38>>38 each.
How much did those two tickets cost?
Thus, two discounted tickets amount to $38 x 2 = $<<38*2=76>>76.
How much did the other ten tickets cost?
And the other ten tickets amount to $40 x 10 = $<<40*10=400>>400.
How much did Mr. Benson pay in all?
Hence, Mr. Benson paid a total of $400 + $76 = $<<400+76=476>>476.

context: Liza bought 10 kilograms of butter to make cookies. She used one-half of it for chocolate chip cookies, one-fifth of it for peanut butter cookies, and one-third of the remaining butter for sugar cookies.
main-q: How many kilograms of butter are left after making those three kinds of cookies?

Liza used 10/2 = <<10/2=5>>5 kilograms of butter for the chocolate chip cookies.
How many kilograms of butter did Liza use for the peanut butter cookies?
Then, she used 10/5 = <<10/5=2>>2 kilograms of butter for the peanut butter cookies.
How many kilograms of butter did Liza use for the chocolate and peanut butter cookies?
She used 5 + 2 = <<5+2=7>>7 kilograms of butter for the chocolate and peanut butter cookies.
How many kilograms of butter were left after making those three kinds of cookies?
So, only 10 -7 = <<10-7=3>>3 kilograms of butter was left.
How many kilograms of butter did Liza use for the sugar cookies?
Then, Liza used 3/3 = <<3/3=1>>1 kilograms of butter for the sugar cookies.
How many kilograms of butter were left after making those three kinds of cookies?
Therefore, only 3-1 = <<3-1=2>>2 kilograms of butter were left.

context: Every hour Joanne has to collect the coins out of the fountain inside the mall. During the first hour, she collected 15 coins. 15 coins collected in hour one.

35 coins collected in hour three.

50 coins collected in hour four.

Before giving her coworker some coins there were 15+35+35+50=<<15+35+35+50=135>>135 coins.

The number of coins after given 15 to her coworker is 135-15=<<135-15=120>>120.

context: Tara has been planning to buy a laptop which costs $1000. A computer shop accepts payment in installments of $65 per month provided that a 20% down payment is made.
main-q: If Tara wants to pay an additional $20 for the down payment, how much will her balance be after paying for 4 months?
qa-pairs: How much is the down payment?
Tara has to make a $1000 x 20/100 = $<<1000*20/100=200>>200 down payment.
How much is the total down payment?
Since Tara wants to pay $20 more for the down payment, her total down payment will be $200 + $20 = $<<200+20=220>>220.
How much is the remaining balance?
So her remaining balance payable over a year is $1000 - $220 = $<<1000-220=780>>780.
How much is the monthly payment?
Tara has to make a monthly payment of $780/year / 12 months/year = $<<780/12=65>>65/month.
How much is the total cost of the payments?
The total cost of her payments for 4 months is $65/month x 4 months = $<<65*4=260>>260.
How much is Tara's balance after 4 months?
Therefore, Tara's balance after 4 months is $780 - $260 = $<<780-260=520>>520.

context: Jesse and Mia are competing in a week long race. They have one week to run 30 miles. On the first three days Jesse averages (2/3) of a mile. On day four she runs 10 miles. Mia averages 3 miles a day over the first 4 days.
main-q: What is the average of their average that they have to run over the final three days?
qa-pairs: How many miles does Jesse run in the first three days?
Jesse runs 2 miles in the first three days because 3 x (2/3) = <<3*(2/3)=2>>2.
How many miles does Jesse have left to run?
Jesse has 18 miles left to run because 30 - 10 - 2 = <<30-10-2=18>>18.
How many miles does Jesse have to run?
Jesse has to run an average of 6 miles a day because 18 / 3 = <<18/3=6>>6.
How many miles does Mia run in the first four days?
Mia runs 12 miles over the first four days because 4 x 3 = <<4*3=12>>12.
How many miles does Mia have left to run?
She has 18 miles left to run because 30 - 12 = <<30-12=18>>18.
How many miles does Mia have to run?
She has to run six miles a day because 18 / 3 = <<18/3=6>>6.

context: Sam and Jeff had a skipping competition at recess. The competition was split into four rounds. Sam completed 1 more skip than Jeff in the first round. Jeff skipped 3 fewer times than Sam in the second round. Jeff skipped 4 more times than Sam in the third round. Jeff got tired and only completed half the number of skips as Sam in the last round.
main-q: If Sam skipped 16 times in each round, what is the average number of skips per round completed by Jeff?
qa-pairs: How many skips did Jeff complete in round one?
In round one, Jeff completed 16 - 1 = <<16-1=15>>15.
How many skips did Jeff complete in round two?
In round two, Jeff completed 16 - 3 = <<16-3=13>>13.
How many skips did Jeff complete in round three?
In round three, Jeff completed 16 + 4 = <<16+4=20>>20.
How many skips did Jeff complete in round four?
In round four, Jeff completed 16 / 2 = <<16/2=8>>8.
How many skips did Jeff complete in total?
Jeff completed 15 + 13 + 20 + 8 = <<15+13+20+8=56>>56 skips in total.
What is the average number of skips per round completed by Jeff?
Jeff skipped an average of 56 / 4 = <<56/4=14>>14 skips per round.

context: Paityn has 20 red hats and 24 blue hats. Her friend Zola has 4/5 times as many red hats as she has and twice the number of blue hats. If they combine all the hats together and share them equally between themselves, calculate the number of hats each gets.
qa-pairs: How many hats does Paityn have?
Paityn has a total of 20 hats + 24 hats = <<20+24=44>>44 hats.
How many red hats does Zola have?
The number of red hats that Zola has is 4/5 * 20 hats = <<4/5*20=16>>16 hats.
How many blue hats does Zola have?
Zola also has 2 * 24 hats = <<2*24=48>>48 blue hats.
How many hats does Zola have?
Zola has a total of 48 hats + 16 hats = <<48+16=64>>64 hats.
How many hats do they have together?
When they combine their hats, they have 64 hats + 44 hats = <<64+44=108>>108 hats.
How many hats does each person get?
If they share the hats equally, each get 108 hats / 2 people = <<108/2=54>>54 hats/person.

context: Alice has 20 quarters. She wants to exchange them for nickels and so she goes to the bank. After getting back from the bank, she discovers that 20% of the nickels are iron nickels worth $3 each.

She gets 100 nickels from the bank because 20 x 5 = <<20*5=100>>100.
How many of the nickels are iron nickels?
20 of the nickels are iron nickels because 100 x .20 = <<100*.20=20>>20.

80 of the nickels are regular because 100 - 20 = <<100-20=80>>80.

The iron nickels are worth $60 because 20 x 3 = <<20*3=60>>60.

The regular nickels are worth $4 because 80 x .05 = <<80*.05=4>>4.

context: Janice can type 6 sentences per minute. Today at work, Janice continued working on a paper she started typing yesterday. She typed for 20 minutes, took a break, and typed 15 minutes longer. She then had to erase 40 sentences she had typed incorrectly. After a meeting, she typed for 18 minutes more. In all, the paper had 536 sentences by the end of today.

Janice typed 6 * 20 = <<6*20=120>>120 sentences before her break.

She typed 6 * 15 = <<6*15=90>>90 sentences after her break.
How many sentences did Janice type after her meeting?
She typed 6 * 18 = <<6*18=108>>108 sentences after her meeting.

Therefore, she typed 120 + 90 + 108 = <<120+90+108=318>>318 sentences today in all.
How many sentences did Janie have left after erasing?

context: There is very little car traffic on Happy Street. During the week, most cars pass it on Tuesday - 25. On Monday, 20% less than on Tuesday, and on Wednesday, 2 more cars than on Monday. On Thursday and Friday, it is about 10 cars each day. On the weekend, traffic drops to 5 cars per day.

On the weekend 5 * 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 cars are passing.

context: Valerie needs to put stamps on the envelopes she is about to mail. She has thank you cards for each of her grandmother, uncle and aunt for the birthday presents they sent. She also has to pay the water bill and the electric bill separately. She wants to send three more mail-in rebates than she does bills and she has twice as many job applications as rebates to mail.

context: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate.
main-q: How many hours did filling the truck take?
qa-pairs: How many blocks did Stella and Twinkle fill up the truck in an hour?
Stella and Twinkle filled up the truck at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person, a total of 2*250 = <<250*2=500>>500 blocks per hour for both.
How many blocks did Stella and Twinkle fill up the truck in four hours?
After working for four hours, Stella and Twinkle had filled 4*500 = <<4*500=2000>>2000 blocks into the truck.
How many blocks did Stella and Twinkle have to put into the truck for it to be full?
The number of blocks they had to put into the truck for it to be full is 6000-2000 = <<6000-2000=4000>>4000.
How many people were filling the truck now?
When 6 more people joined Stella and Twinkle, a total of 2+6 = <<2+6=8>>8 people were filling the truck now.
How many blocks did the eight people fill the truck in an hour?
Working at the rate of 250 blocks per person, the eight people filled the truck with 250*8 = <<250*8=2000>>2000 blocks in one hour.
How many hours did the 8 people take to fill the truck?
If there were 4000 blocks that still needed to be put into the truck, the 8 people took 4000/2000 = <<4000/2000=2>>2 hours to fill the truck with the blocks.

context: Daniel has a collection of 346 video games. 80 of them, Daniel bought for $12 each. Of the rest, 50% were bought for $7. All others had a price of $3 each.

How many games are left?

50% of these games means 50/100 * 266 games = <<50/100*266=133>>133 games.

context: Lisa and Carly go shopping together. Lisa spends $40 on t-shirts then spends half of this amount on jeans and twice this amount on coats. Carly spends only a quarter as much as Lisa on t-shirts but spends 3 times as much on jeans and a quarter of the amount Lisa spent on coats.

context: Madeline has 5 boxes with 24 crayons in each. She noticed that 5/8 of the crayons in the 2 boxes were not yet used. In the 2 other boxes, only 2/3 of the crayons were used while the last box was not entirely used.
main-q: How many unused crayons did Madeline have?

Two boxes of crayons have 24 x 5/8 = <<24*5/8=15>>15 unused crayons from each box.

context: In a section of the forest, there are 100 weasels and 50 rabbits. Three foxes invade this region and hunt the rodents. Each fox catches an average of 4 weasels and 2 rabbits per week.
main-q: How many rabbits and weasels will be left after 3 weeks?
qa-pairs: How many weasels do the foxes catch each week?
3 foxes catch 4 weasels each every week for a total of 3*4 = <<3*4=12>>12 weasels.
How many weasels are caught in total?
12 weasels are caught every week for 3 weeks for a total of 12*3 = <<12*3=36>>36 weasels.
How many rabbits do the foxes catch each week?
3 foxes catch 2 rabbits each every week for a total of 3*2 = <<3*2=6>>6 rabbits.
How many rabbits are caught in total?

There were originally 100 weasels so now there are 100-36 = <<100-36=64>>64 weasels left.

context: Apple sold 100 iPhones at their New York store today for an average cost of $1000. They also sold 20 iPads for an average cost of $900 and 80 Apple TVs for an average cost of $200.

context: Rosie runs 6 miles per hour. She runs for 1 hour on Monday, 30 minutes on Tuesday, 1 hour on Wednesday, and 20 minutes on Thursday.

qa-pairs: How many miles does Rosie run on Monday and Wednesday?

So far this week Rosie has run 6+3+6+2=<<6+3+6+2=17>>17 miles.

context: Last year Jessica paid $1000 for rent, $200 for food, and $100 for car insurance each month. This year her rent goes up by 30%, food costs increase by 50%, and the cost of her car insurance triples because she was at fault in an accident.
main-q: How much more does Jessica pay for her expenses over the whole year compared to last year?

context: Cary is an engineer in charge of designing an irrigation system for three farmers. Farmer Bob grows 3 acres of corn, 9 acres of cotton, and 12 acres of beans. context: Carol is an aviation engineer deciding how much fuel to put in a jet. The empty plane needs 20 gallons of fuel per mile. Each person on the plane increases this amount by 3 gallons per mile, and each bag increases it by 2 gallons per mile.

Then find the fuel increase caused by the people by multiplying their number by the fuel increase per person: 35 people * 3 gallons/mile/person = <<35*3=105>>105 gallons/mile.

Then multiply the number of bags by the fuel increase per bag to find the total fuel increase they cause: 70 bags * 2 gallons/mile/bag = <<70*2=140>>140 gallons/mile.

Now add the fuel increases to the base fuel consumption to find the total fuel needed per mile: 140 gallons/mile + 105 gallons/mile + 20 gallons/mile = <<140+105+20=265>>265 gallons/mile.

Now multiply the fuel consumption per mile by the number of miles flown to find the total amount of fuel needed: 265 gallons/mile * 400 miles = <<265*400=106000>>106,000 gallons of fuel.

context: Yolanda leaves home for work at 7:00 AM, riding her bike at 20 miles per hour. 15 minutes after she leaves, her husband realizes that she forgot her lunch, and jumps in the car to bring it to her.

Yolanda's husband catches up to her when they've both traveled the same distance, which is when 20(x + 15) = 40x.

context: Jason is counting the number of cars that drive by his window. He counted four times as many green cars as red cars, and 6 more red cars than purple cars.

Combine like terms?
Now combine like terms to get 6p + 30 = 312.

Now subtract 30 from both sides to get 6p = 282.

Now divide both sides by 6 to get p = 47.

context: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant.

context: Monica and Sheila are twins. Their mother gave them $50 and told them to buy some toilet paper and spend the remainder on groceries. The toilet paper cost $12. context: Hasan is packing up his apartment because he’s moving across the country for a new job. He needs to ship several boxes to his new home. The movers have asked that Hasan avoid putting more than a certain weight in pounds in any cardboard box. The moving company has helpfully provided Hasan with a digital scale that will alert him if a package is too heavy. Hasan is in the kitchen, and he fills a cardboard box with 38 dinner plates. When he checks the box, the scale reports his box is too heavy. Hasan knows each of his plates weighs 10 ounces. He removes a single plate from the box and checks the movers’ scale again. The scale reports his box is still too heavy. Hasan repeats the process again and again. When he has removed enough plates, the movers’ scale shows the box is now an acceptable weight for shipping. Hasan deduces that each shipping box can hold 20 pounds before the scale says the box is too heavy.
main-q: How many plates did Hasan need to remove from the shipping box?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x be the number of plates removed from the box.
How many ounces can each box hold?
Hasan figured out the movers' weight limit was 20 pounds. Since a pound is equal to 16 ounces, each box can hold 20 * 16, or <<20*16=320>>320 ounces.
How many ounces are in the box after Hasan removes enough plates?
Each plate weighs 10 ounces, so the weight of the plates in the box after Hasan removes enough plates to satisfy the movers' weight limit is (38 - x) * 10 ounces.
Write an equation?
Since these two values are equal, we can write the equation (38 - x) * 10 = 320.
Simplify?
Dividing both sides by 10 leaves 38-x = 32.
Simplify?
Adding x to both sides gives 38 – x + x = 32 +x, or, 38 = 32 +x.

context: On his farm, Mr. Mathews has goats and sheep in the ratio of 5:7. He decides to sell half of the goats at $40 each and 2/3 of the sheep at $30 each.

context: A jar on the family's counter contains change they've been saving a trip to the ice cream shop. There are 123 pennies, 85 nickels, 35 dimes, and a number of quarters. All five family members get a double scoop, which costs $3 each. After the trip, they have 48 cents left over.

context: The American swallow can lift into the air and carry a maximum of 5 pounds of weight, while the European swallow can lift and carry twice the weight as the American swallow.

And the number of American swallows is 90-30=<<90-30=60>>60.

30 European swallows can carry a maximum of 30*10=<<30*10=300>>300 pounds.

context: Joseph had socks of many different colors. His dresser drawer was filled to overflowing with red, blue, black, and white socks. He had one less pair of red socks than he had pairs of white socks. He had twice as many blue socks as he had of red socks. And he counted a total of 6 red socks.

context: Rita is reading a five-chapter book with 95 pages. Each chapter has three pages more than the previous one.

context: Jacque arrived in France and his suitcase weighed 5 pounds.  While in France, he picked up 5 bottles of perfume that weighed 1.2 ounces each, 4 pounds of chocolate, 2 bars of soap that weighed 5 ounces each and 2 jars of jam that weighed 8 ounces each.

context: Lyla, a grocery store owner, bought rice weighing 30 kg less than green beans, which weigh 10 kg more than sugar. While carrying the goods to the store, the bags fell down and 1/3 weight of the rice and 1/5 weight of sugar was lost.

context: A local college is offering German lessons and currently has 8 students enrolled. context: Samuel has $5, $10, and $20 bills which amount to $150 in his wallet. His $10-bills amount to $50, and he has 4 $20-bills.

context: Hugo can fold a small box in 3 seconds and a medium one in twice that time. Tom can fold both the small and medium boxes in 4 seconds.
main-q: If Hugo and Tom want to leave as early as possible, how long (in seconds) will it take them to fold 2400 small boxes and 1800 medium boxes?

How many seconds does Tom take to fold a medium box?

How many seconds does Hugo take to fold a small box?

Therefore Hugo should fold all small boxes and Tom should fold all the medium ones before doing the other size where they are slower.

If there are 1800 medium boxes and Tom can fold 1 box in 4 seconds, then it would take him 1800*4 = <<1800*4=7200>>7200 seconds to fold all medium boxes.

context: Martha needs to paint all four walls in her 12 foot by 16 foot kitchen, which has 10 foot high ceilings. Each wall needs one coat of primer and two coats of paint.

Now multiply that amount by 3 because Martha needs to add 3 coats: 560 sq ft/coat * 3 coats = <<560*3=1680>>1680 sq ft.

context: The area of square A is 25. The area of square B is 81.

context: Billy and Margaret are competing with each other to see who can swim 10 laps the fastest. context: Bill milked his cow and got 16 gallons of milk. He turned 1/4 into sour cream, 1/4 into butter, and kept the rest as whole milk. It takes 4 gallons of milk to make one gallon of butter and 2 gallons of milk to make 1 gallon of sour cream.

context: Mr. Willson worked on making his furniture for 3/4 an hour on Monday. On Tuesday, he worked for half an hour. Then he worked for 2/3 an hour on Wednesday and 5/6 of an hour on Thursday.

context: Miss Smith is teaching second period English and is shocked at how small the class seems. There are 6 tables in the classroom with 3 students currently sitting at each table. context: A particular train has some passenger cars and a number of cargo cars equal to half the number of passenger cars plus three.
main-q: If the total number of cars is 71, counting the engine and caboose, how many passenger cars are in the train?

How many cars are there?
Let p be the number of passenger cars and c be the number of cargo cars. We know that p + c = 69 and c = p/2 + 3.

Substituting the second equation into the first, we get p + p/2 + 3 = 69.
Combine like terms?
Combining like terms, we get 1.5p + 3 = 69.

Subtracting 3 from both sides, we get 1.5p = 66.

Dividing both sides by 1.5, we get p = 44.

context: Five years ago, the sum of Sebastian's age and his sister's age was 3/4 of their father's age.

context: Kim loves to knit sweaters and can knit as many as 10 sweaters in a day if she gets the time. context: A large gathering occurred at the town hall with 200 people participating. 100 people decided to have a snack, and then 20 new outsiders joined in to have a snack. context: The ratio of the amount of money Cara, Janet, and Jerry have is 4:5:6. If the total amount of money they have is $75, calculate the loss Cara and Janet will make if they combine their money to buy oranges and sell them at 80% of the buying price.

context: Lily got a new puppy for her birthday.  She was responsible for feeding the puppy 1/4 cup of food three times a day for two weeks starting tomorrow.  For the following 2 weeks, Lily will feed him 1/2 cup of food twice a day.  She has fed him 1/2 cup of food today.

context: Daryl is loading crates at a warehouse and wants to make sure that they are not overloaded. Each crate can weigh up to 20kg and he has 15 crates he can fill. context: Casey is pumping water out of her well. She can pump 3 gallons a minute. She has 4 rows of 15 corn plants each, and each plant needs half a gallon of water. She also has 10 pigs, which each need 4 gallons of water, and 20 ducks that each need a quarter of a gallon of water.

How many gallons of water do the pigs need?
Then find how many gallons of water the pigs need: 10 pigs * 4 gallons/pig = <<10*4=40>>40 gallons.
How many gallons of water do the ducks need?

context: Gilbert, the bearded dragon, eats 4 crickets per week when the temperature averages 90 degrees F per day, but he eats twice as many crickets per week when the temperature averages 100 degrees F.

context: Four days ago, Carlos bought a bag of gummy worms. Every day he ate half of the remaining gummy worms. After eating half of the remainder on the fourth day, he now has 4 gummy worms left.

Thus, there were G = 4 * 16 = <<4*16=64>>64 gummy worms in the bag when Carlos bought it.

context: Arnold owns three cars. The first car averages 50 miles per gallon of gas. The second car averages 10 miles per gallon of gas. And the third car averages 15 miles per gallon of gas. He splits his 450-mile monthly driving mileage equally amongst his three cars.

This will cost him $56 because 28 x $2 = $<<28*2=56>>56.

context: Bill and Phil are firehouse Dalmatians. Bill has one less than twice as many spots as Phil.
main-q: If they have 59 spots combined, how many spots does Bill have?
qa-pairs: How many spots does Bill have?
If b is the number of spots Bill has and p is the number of spots Phil has, we know that b + p = 59. We also know that b = 2p - 1.
How many spots does Bill have?

How many spots does Bill have?
Combining like terms, we get 3p - 1= 59.

Adding 1 to both sides, we get 3p = 60.
How many spots does Phil have?
Dividing both sides by 3, we get p = 20.
How many spots does Bill have?
Substituting this back into the equation b = 2p - 1, we get b = 2*20 - 1 = 40 - 1 = <<2*20-1=39>>39.

context: A school canteen sells a sandwich at $2, a hamburger at $2, one stick of hotdog at $1, and a can of fruit juice at $2 each can. Selene buys three sandwiches and a can of fruit juice. Tanya buys two hamburgers and two cans of fruit juice.

context: Kendra tracks the different species of birds they spot on their birdwatching trip. On Monday they visited 5 sites and saw an average of 7 birds at each site. Let x represent the number of hops it took the third frog.
How many hops did the second frog take?
The second frog:2x.
How many hops did the first frog take?
First frog:4(2x)=8x.
Write an equation?
Total:x+2x+8x=99.
Combine like terms?
Divide by 11?

context: Brendan makes $6/hour as a waiter. He's scheduled for 2 8-hour shifts and 1 12-hour shift this week. He also makes an average of $12 in tips each hour. Brendan is supposed to pay 20% of his income in taxes, but he only reports 1/3rd of his tips to the IRS.
main-q: How much money does Brendan pay in taxes each week?
qa-pairs: How many hours does Brendan work in the 8-hour shifts?
First find the total number of hours Brendan works for the 8-hour shifts: 2 shifts * 8 hours/shift = <<2*8=16>>16 hours.
How many hours does Brendan work in total?
Then find the total number of hours Brendan works by adding those hours to the 12-hour shift: 16 hours + 12 hours = <<16+12=28>>28 hours.
How much money does Brendan make in total?
Now find Brendan's total wage earnings by multiplying his $6/hour wage by the number of hours he works: $6/hour * 28 hours = $<<6*28=168>>168/week.
How much money does Brendan make in tips?
Now figure out how much Brendan makes in tips by multiplying the number of hours he works by the amount of tips he makes per hour: $12/hour * 28 hours/week = $<<12*28=336>>336/week.
How much money does Brendan report to the IRS?
Now divide that number by 3, since Brendan only reports a third of his tips: $336/week / 3 = $<<336/3=112>>112/week.
How much money does Brendan report to the IRS?
Now add Brendan's wage earnings to that number to find how much income he reports to the IRS each week: $168/week + $112/week = $<<168+112=280>>280/week.

context: Leonard is 4 years younger than Nina who is half as old as Jerome.
main-q: If the sum of their ages is 36, what is Leonard's age?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x be the age of Nina.
How old is Leonard?
So, Leonard's age is x - 4.
How old is Jerome?
And Jerome's age is 2x.
Write an equation?
Since the sum of their ages is 36, then the equation is x + x - 4 + 2x = 36.
Combine like terms?
By combining like terms, the equation becomes 4x = 40.
How old is Nina?
So the value of x which represents the age of Nina is x = 40/4 = <<40/4=10>>10.

context: James has five huskies, two pitbulls and four golden retrievers, all female. They became pregnant and each golden retriever had two more pups than each husky.
main-q: If the huskies and pitbulls had 3 pups each, How many more pups than adult dogs are there in total?

There are 5+2 = <<5+2=7>>7 huskies and pitbulls.

How many pups are there in total?
There are a total of 21+20 = <<21+20=41>>41 pups.
How many adult dogs are there?
There are a total of 5+2+4 = <<5+2+4=11>>11 adult dogs.

context: Jill is going to resod her front yard. The plot of land in front of her house is 200 feet wide by 50 feet. Her house has a sidewalk that is 3 feet wide and 50 feet long. There are also four flower beds: two right in front of the house that are 4 feet deep by 25 feet long, one that is 10 feet by 12 feet, and a fourth that is 7 feet by 8 feet.
main-q: How many square feet of sod will she need to cover her yard, minus the sidewalk and flower beds?
qa-pairs: How many square feet are in the front yard?
The area of the whole front yard is 200 feet by 50 feet, or 200 ft * 50 ft = <<200*50=10000>>10,000 sq.ft.
How many square feet is the sidewalk?
The sidewalk is 3 feet by 50 feet, or 3ft * 50ft = <<3*50=150>>150 sq.ft.
How many square feet are the flower beds?
Each of the flower beds right in front of the house is 4 feet by 25 feet, or 4 ft * 25 ft = 100 sq.ft. There are two, so that's 2 * 100 sq.ft. = 200 sq.ft.
How many square feet is the third flower bed?
The third flower bed is 10 feet by 12 feet, or 10ft * 12ft = <<10*12=120>>120 sq.ft.
How many square feet is the fourth flower bed?
The fourth flower bed is 7 feet by 8 feet, or 7ft * 8ft = <<7*8=56>>56 sq.ft.
How many square feet are the sidewalk and flower beds?
The total area of the sidewalk and flower beds is 150 sq.ft + 200 sq.ft + 120 sq.ft + 56 sq.ft = <<150+200+120+56=526>>526 sq. ft.

context: Tanesha needs to buy rope so cut into 10 pieces that are each six inches long. She sees a 6-foot length of rope that cost $5 and also sees 1-foot lengths of rope that cost $1.25 each.

The six-foot length of rope would give her 12 pieces because 72 / 6 = <<72/6=12>>12.

The six-foot length is long enough because 12 > 10.
How many inches is each 1-foot rope?
Each 1-foot rope equals 12 inches.
How many 1-foot ropes does Tanesa need?
She would need 5 of the 1-foot ropes because 60 / 12 = <<60/12=5>>5.

context: There is a massive rainstorm lasting 4 days.  There is an area that collects water to prevent flooding in the area.  It ends up overflowing on the 4th day.  The area can hold the equivalent of 6 feet of rain.  It can also drain out the equivalent of 3 inches of rain per day to the nearby river without causing problems.  The first day it rained 10 inches.  The second day it rained twice that much.  On the third day, it rained 50% more than the second day.  It flooded the fourth day before getting a chance to do any of the draining.
main-q: What is the minimum amount it rained on the fourth day?
qa-pairs: How many inches did it rain on the second day?

How many inches did it rain on the third day?
On the third day it rained 20*1.5=<<20*1.5=30>>30 inches.
How many inches did it rain in the first 3 days?
So in the first 3 days, it rained 10+20+30=<<10+20+30=60>>60 inches.
How many days did it drain?
It drained 4-1=<<4-1=3>>3 days.
How many inches did it drain?
So it drained 3*3=<<3*3=9>>9 inches.
How many inches were there on the start of the fourth day?
That means on the start of the fourth day, there were 60-9=<<60-9=51>>51 inches in the pond.

context: Allen is 25 years younger than his mother. In 3 years, the sum of their ages will be 41.
main-q: What is the present age of Allen's mother?
qa-pairs: How many years will it take for the sum of their ages to be 6?
In 3 years, the sum of their present ages will be added by 3 (from Allen) + 3 (from her mother) = <<3+3=6>>6.
What is the present age of Allen's mother?
So, the sum of their present ages is 41 - 6 = <<41-6=35>>35.
Define a variable?
Let x be the present age of Allen's mother and x - 25 be the present age of Allen.
Write an equation?
So the equation using the sum of their present ages is x + x - 25 = 35.
Combine like terms?
By combining like terms, the equation becomes 2x = 60.
How old is Allen's mother?
Hence, Allen's mother is x = 60/2 = <<60/2=30>>30 years old now.

context: Roger's age is 5 more than twice Jill's age. In 15 years, their age difference will be 30 years less than Finley's age.
main-q: If Jill is 20 years old now, how old is Finley?
qa-pairs: How old is Jill?
Twice Jill's age is 2*20=<<2*20=40>>40.
How old is Roger?
If Roger's age is 5 more than twice Jill's age, he is 5+40=45 years old.
How old will Jill be in 15 years?
In 15 years, Jill will be 20+15=<<20+15=35>>35 years old.
How old will Roger be in 15 years?
Roger's age will be 45+15=<<45+15=60>>60 years old in 15 years.
How old will the age difference be in 15 years?
The age difference between Roger and Jill in fifteen years will be 60-35=<<60-35=25>>25 years.
How old will Finley be in 15 years?
In 15 years, the age difference between Roger and Jill will be 30 years less than Finley's age, meaning in fifteen years Finley will be 30+25=<<30+25=55>>55 years old.

context: Delta, Beta and Gamma decided to share 40 donuts. Delta took 8 donuts and Beta took three times as many as Gamma.
main-q: How many donuts did Gamma receive?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x = the number of donuts Gamma took.
How many donuts did Delta and Beta have?
The total donuts Gamma and Beta have is 40 - 8 = <<40-8=32>>32 donuts.
How many donuts did Beta take?
3x is the number of donuts for Beta.
How many donuts did Beta and Gamma have?
3x + x is the number of total donuts for Beta and Gamma.
How many donuts did Beta and Gamma have?
If we add the two x terms, we get 4x = 32.
How many donuts did Gamma take?
If we divide both sides by 4, we get x = 8, so Gamma has 8 donuts.

context: Maddox and Theo both bought 3 Polaroid Cameras, each sold at $20 per camera from Amazon, and decided to sell them on eBay. Maddox sold his cameras at $28 each, while Theo sold his cameras at $23 each.

The total cost of buying 3 cameras from Amazon for both Maddox and Theo was 3*$20=$<<3*20=60>>60.

Maddox sold his cameras at $28 each, for a total of $28*3=$<<28*3=84>>84.

Maddox made a profit of $84-$60=$<<84-60=24>>24 from the sale of his cameras.

Theo sold his cameras on eBay for $23*3=$<<23*3=69>>69.
How much profit did Theo make?
Theo made a profit of $69-$60=$<<69-60=9>>9.

Maddox made $24-$9=$15 more profit than Theo from the sale of his cameras.

context: Barry wants to make a huge salad using only cucumbers and tomatoes. He will use a total of 280 pieces of vegetables.
main-q: If there are thrice as many tomatoes as cucumbers, how many cucumbers will be used in the salad?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let c be the number of cucumbers and t the number of tomatoes.
Write an equation?
The total is the sum of the number of cucumbers and that of tomatoes, which is c + t = 280 piece of vegetables.
How many cucumbers are there?
Since there are thrice as many tomatoes as cucumbers, this means c =t/3.
How many cucumbers are there?
Therefore 3*c = t.
Write an equation?
The sum will therefore be c + 3*c = 280 pieces of vegetables.
Simplify?
This means that 4*c = 280 vegetables.

context: Jill runs a business breeding llamas. Nine of her llamas got pregnant with 1 calf, and 5 of them got pregnant with twins. After they give birth, Jill traded 8 of the calves for 2 new adult llamas. Then she sells 1/3 of her herd at the market.
main-q: How many total llamas  (calves and adults) does Jill have now?
qa-pairs: How many calves will be born as twins?
The number of calves that will be born as twins is 5 * 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 calves.
How many adults and calves are there before the trade?
The total number of adults and calves before the trade is 9 + 5 + 9 + 10 = <<9+5+9+10=33>>33.
How many calves did Jill trade?
Jill had 33 - 8 = <<33-8=25>>25 left for trading 8 of the claves.
How many llamas does Jill have now?
But, she got 2 adult llamas in return, so she now has a total of 25 + 2 = <<25+2=27>>27 llamas.
How many llamas did Jill sell?
She then sold 27 / 3 = <<27/3=9>>9 llamas in the market.

So, Jill has 27 - 9 = <<27-9=18>>18 llamas now.

context: Frank spent 1/5 of his money to buy groceries. He then spent 1/4 of the remaining money to buy a magazine.
main-q: If he had $360 left in his wallet, how much money did he have at first?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let X be the money Frank had originally.
How much money did Frank spend on groceries?
Frank spent 1/5*X on groceries.
How much money did Frank spend on a magazine?
Frank spent 1/4*(X-1/5*X) on a magazine.
How much money did Frank have left in his wallet?
Frank has X - 1/5*X - 1/4*(X-1/5*X) = $360 left in his wallet.
Write an equation?
Multiplying through the parentheses, we get X - 1/5*X - 1/4*X + 1/20*X = $360.
Simplify?
Combining like terms, we get 12/20*X = $360.

context: Nigella is a realtor who earns a base salary of $3,000 a month plus a 2% commission on every house she sells. One month, Nigella sells 3 houses and earns $8,000 total. House B costs three times as much as House A. House C cost twice as much as House A minus $110,000.
main-q: How much did House A cost?
qa-pairs: How much money did Nigella earn from commission?
First figure out how much money Nigella earned from commission by subtracting her base salary from her total earnings: $8,000 - $3,000 = $<<8000-3000=5000>>5,000.
How much did all three houses cost?
Next, figure out how much all three houses cost by dividing Nigella's commission money by her commission rate: $5,000 ÷ 0.02 = $<<5000/0.02=250000>>250,000.
How much did House B and C cost?
Next, express each house's price in terms of A's price: B = 3A, and C = 2A - $110,000.
Write an equation?
Now we know that A + 3A + 2A - $110,000 = $250,000.
Combine like terms?
We can combine like terms to find that 6A - $110,000 = $250,000.
Add $110,000 to both sides?
Now we add $110,000 to both sides of the equation and get 6A = $360,000.

context: Steve writes a letter every 3rd day to his friend.  He spends 20 minutes writing the letters.  It takes 10 minutes to write 1 page.  He also writes a long letter at the end of the month which he puts more thought into.  It takes twice as long per page but he spends 80 minutes writing.

How many pages does Steve write in a month?

context: A case of water contains 24 bottles. A children's camp comprising of 4 groups purchased 13 cases for a 3-day camp. context: An archer needs to practice.  He intends to shoot 200 shots 4 days a week.  He is able to recover 20% of his arrows.  The arrows he uses cost $5.5 per arrow.  His team agrees to pay for 70% of the cost of his arrows.

context: Tobias went to a swimming pool for 3 hours. Swimming every 100 meters took him 5 minutes, but every 25 minutes he had to take a 5-minute pause.
main-q: How many meters did Tobias swim during his visit to the swimming pool?
qa-pairs: How many minutes are in each sequence?
We need to count the sequences that Tobias made, which consist of 25 minutes of swimming and a 5-minute pause, so one sequence lasts for 25 minutes + 5 minutes = <<25+5=30>>30 minutes/sequence.
How many sequences does Tobias make?
Three hours is 3 hours * 60 minutes/hour = 180 minutes, so he is able to make 180 minutes / 30 minutes/sequence = <<180/30=6>>6 sequences.
How many minutes are in each pause?
Therefore Tobias needs to make 6 pauses within these 6 sequences, which will last for 6 pauses * 5 minutes/pause = <<6*5=30>>30 minutes.
How many minutes does Tobias swim?
During three hours, he is going to swim for 180 minutes - 30 minutes = <<180-30=150>>150 minutes.
How many meters does Tobias swim?
Therefore Tobias can make 100 meters for 150 minutes / 5 minutes/100 meters = 3 times.
How many meters did Tobias swim?
So he was able to swim 30 times * 100 meters/time = <<30*100=3000>>3000 meters in total.

context: Annie is building a diorama for her history class. The amount of time she spent building it is equal to three times the amount of time she spent planning it minus 5 minutes.
main-q: If she spent 67 minutes on the diorama total, how many minutes did she spend building it?
qa-pairs: How many minutes did Annie spend building the diorama?
Let p be the planning time in minutes and b be the building time. We know that b = 3p - 5 and b + p = 67.
Write an equation?
Substituting the first equation into the second equation, we get 3p - 5 + p = 67.
Combine like terms?
Combining like terms, we get 4p - 5 = 67.
Add 5 to both sides?
Adding 5 to both sides, we get 4p = 72.
Divide by 4?
Dividing both sides by 4, we get p = 18.
How many minutes did Annie spend building the diorak?
Substituting this value into b = 3p - 5, we find that b = 3 * 18 - 5 = <<3*18-5=49>>49.

context: Rich likes to take long walks through town.  First he walks 20 feet from his house to the sidewalk.  Then he walks 200 feet down the sidewalk to the end of the road.  Then he makes a left and walks double his total distance so far until he reaches the next intersection.  Then he walks half the total distance up to this point again to the end of his route, before turning around and walking the same path all the way back home.

How far does Rich walk?
This makes a total of 220+440= <<220+440=660>>660 feet.
How far does Rich walk?
He then walks half that distance, 660/2= <<660/2=330>>330 feet to get to the end of his route.
How far does Rich walk?
This makes a total of 660+330=<<660+330=990>>990 feet so far.
How far does Rich walk?
He then walks that same distance back, for a total of 990*2= <<990*2=1980>>1980 feet in total.

context: On the weekend, Tony will walk to the store. On weekdays, he runs to the store. When he walks, he goes 2 MPH. When he runs he goes 10 MPH. The store is 4 miles away.

context: Haley is making cider. It takes 20 golden delicious apples and 40 pink lady apples to make one pint of cider. Each of her 6 farmhands can pick 240 apples per hour and will work 5 hours today.

Then multiply that number by 8 to find the number of apples needed for a gallon of cider: 60 apples/pint * 8 pints/gallon = <<60*8=480>>480 apples/gallon.
How many apples do the farmhands pick in an hour?
Now find how many apples per hour all 8 farmhands pick: 240 apples/hour/farmhand * 6 farmhands = <<240*6=1440>>1440 apples/hour.

Then multiply that amount by the number of hours worked to find the total number of apples gathered: 1440 apples/hour * 5 hours = <<1440*5=7200>>7200 apples.

Divide the total number of apples gathered by the number of apples used by gallon to find the number of gallons of cider made: 7200 apples / 480 apples/gallon = <<7200/480=15>>15 gallons.

Since there are 8 pints in a gallon, the final answer is 15 gallons * 8 pints / gallon = <<15*8=120>>120 pints.

context: Linda is painting her bedroom. Her bedroom has 4 walls, with the room being 20 feet wide by 20 feet long by 8 feet tall. One wall has a 3-foot by 7-foot doorway. context: Trevor is a comic book illustrator. In the past three months, he has drawn 220 pages of the comic. The comic he illustrates releases a new issue once a month. The first and second months’ issues were the same number of pages, but the third month’s issue was four pages longer than either of the others.

qa-pairs: Define a variable?

How many pages are the first and second issues?
The second issue is the same number of pages, so the first and second issues are P + P = 2P pages.

All three issues are 2P + P + 4 = 3P + 4 = 220 pages long.
How many pages are the first, second, and third issues?
Thus, 3P = 220 - 4 = 216 pages.

Therefore, the first issue of the comic was P = 216 / 3 = <<216/3=72>>72 pages.

context: A road has four intersections. At the first intersection, there are 40 road signs showing different types of information mounted on the street poles. context: The cheerleading coach is ordering new uniforms. There are 4 cheerleaders who need a size 2, a certain number who need a size 6, and half that number who need a size 12.
main-q: If there are 19 cheerleaders total, how many cheerleaders need a size 6?
qa-pairs: How many cheerleaders need a size 6?
Let s be the number of cheerleaders who need a size 6 and t be the number who need a size 12. We know that s = 2t and s + t + 4 = 19.
How many cheerleaders need a size 12?
Substituting the first equation into the second equation, we get 2t + t + 4 = 19.
How many cheerleaders need a size 12?
Combining like terms, we get 3t + 4 = 19.
How many cheerleaders need a size 12?
Subtracting 4 from both sides, we get 3t = 15.
How many cheerleaders need a size 12?
Dividing both sides by 3, we get t = 5.
How many cheerleaders need a size 6?
Substituting that value back into the equation s = 2t, we get s = 2 * 5 = <<2*5=10>>10.

context: Angelo and Melanie want to plan how many hours over the next week they should study together for their test next week. context: Karen's students are about to take a standardized test. Karen gets a $500 bonus if their average score is above 75, plus an extra $10 bonus for every additional point the average score increases above 75. So far, Karen has graded 8 tests, and the average is 70.

context: Hank reads the newspaper every morning, 5 days a week for 30 minutes.  He reads part of a novel every evening, 5 days a week, for 1 hour.  He doubles his reading time on Saturday and Sundays.
main-q: How many minutes does Hank spend reading in 1 week?
qa-pairs: How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the morning?
He reads 30 minutes in the morning 5 days a week for a total of 30*5 = <<30*5=150>>150 minutes.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the morning?
He doubles his reading time on the weekends so 30*2 = <<30*2=60>>60 minutes per day.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the morning?
He reads 60 minutes on Saturday and Sunday in the mornings for a total of 60+60 = <<60+60=120>>120 minutes.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the evening?
He reads 1 hour in the evenings 5 days a week for a total of 1*5 = <<1*5=5>>5 hours.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the evening?
He doubles his reading time on the weekends so 1*2 = <<1*2=2>>2 hours per day.
How many minutes does Hank spend reading in the evening?
He reads 2 hours on Saturday and Sunday in the evenings for a total of 2+2 = <<2+2=4>>4 hours.

context: Darrel has 76 quarters, 85 dimes, 20 nickels and 150 pennies.  If he drops all of his money into a coin-counting machine, they will convert his change into dollars for a 10% fee.
main-q: How much will he receive after the 10% fee?
qa-pairs: How much are his quarters?
How much are his dimes?
How much are his nickels?
How much are his pennies?
How much is his total change?
How much will they charge him?
They charge a 10% fee to count and convert his change into dollars so they will charge him .10*30 = $3.00.

context: A man divides 3 hectares of land evenly among his 8 sons.
main-q: If every 750m^2 of this land can be used to make a profit of $500 from every 3 months of commercial farming, how much can each son make if they cultivate their share of the land for one year(1 hectare is equal to 10000 m^2)?
qa-pairs: How many m^2 are in each hectare?
There are 10000m^2 in each hectare, so 3 hectares contains 3*10000 = 30000m^2 of land.
How many m^2 will each son get?
30000m^2 is divided among 8 sons so each son will get 30000/8 = <<30000/8=3750>>3750m^2.
How many portions are in each 3750m^2?
In every 3750m^2, there are 3750/750 = <<3750/750=5>>5 portions of 750m^2 areas of land.
How much can each son make if they cultivate their share of the land for one year?
Each son can make 5*$500 = $<<5*500=2500>>2500 every 3 months from cultivating their share.
How many times can each son make $2500 in a year?
In one year there are 12 months so each son can make $2500 up to 12/3 = <<12/3=4>>4 times in a year.
How much can each son make if they cultivate their share of the land for one year?
Each son can make a total of $2500*4 = $<<2500*4=10000>>10000 in a year.

context: Gina chooses what she and her sister will watch on Netflix three times as often as her sister does.
main-q: If her sister watches a total of 24 shows on Netflix per week, and each show is 50 minutes long, how many minutes of Netflix does Gina get to choose?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let g be the number of shows Gina chooses and s be the number her sister chooses. We know that g = 3s and g + s = 24.
Write an equation?
Substituting the first equation into the second equation, we get 3s + s = 24.
Combine like terms?
Combining like terms, we get 4s = 24.
Divide by 4?
Dividing both sides by 4, we get s = 6.
How many shows does Gina choose?
Substituting this value back into g = 3s, we get g = 3 * 6 = <<3*6=18>>18.
How many minutes of Netflix does Gina get to choose?
Then multiply the number of shows by the length of each show in minutes to find the total number of minutes Gina chooses: 18 shows * 50 minutes/show = <<18*50=900>>900 minutes.

context: It took Dad 5 more than twice as long to vacuum upstairs then to vacuum downstairs. He vacuumed for a total of 38 minutes.
main-q: How many minutes did he vacuum upstairs?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let D = time in minutes to vacuum downstairs.
How long did it take to vacuum upstairs?
Upstairs = 2D + 5 minutes.
Write an equation?
Simplify?
Divide by 3?
How long did it take to vacuum upstairs?

context: Tapanga and Corey have 66 candies together. However, Tapanga has 8 more candies than Corey.
main-q: How many candies does Corey have?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x = the total number of candies Corey has.
How many candies does Tapanga have?
x + 8 = the total number of candies Tapanga has.
Write an equation?
The equation for the total number of candies is x + (x + 8) = 66.
Combine like terms?
Combining like terms, we get 2x + 8 = 66.
Subtract 8?
Subtracting 8 from both sides, we get 2x = 58.
How many candies does Corey have?
Dividing both sides by 2, we get x = <<29=29>>29, so Corey has 29 candies.

context: Michael and Thomas are selling their lego collections. They agree to split any money they earn. They sell them based on how many circles are on top. Each circle costs 1 cent. They earned $5 each after selling 100 single pieces, 45 double pieces, 50 triple pieces and a number of quadruple pieces.
main-q: How many quadruple pieces did they sell?
qa-pairs: How much money did they make?
They made $10 because 2 x 5 = <<2*5=10>>10.
How much money did they make off single pieces?
They made $1 off single pieces because 100 x .01 = <<100*.01=1>>1.
How much money did they make off double pieces?
They made $.9 off double pieces because 45 x .02 = <<45*.02=.9>>.9.
How much money did they make off triple pieces?
They made $1.5 off triple pieces because 50 x .03 = <<50*.03=1.5>>1.5.
How much money did they earn off the first three types?
They earned $3.4 off the first three types because 1 + .9 + 1.5 = <<1+.9+1.5=3.4>>3.4.
How much money did they earn off the quadruroes?
They earned $6.6 off the quadruple pieces because 10 - 3.4 = <<10-3.4=6.6>>6.6.

context: In a certain school, 2/3 of the male students like to play basketball, but only 1/5 of the female students like to play basketball.
main-q: What percent of the population of the school do not like to play basketball if the ratio of the male to female students is 3:2 and there are 1000 students?
qa-pairs: How many parts are there?
The students are divided into 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5 parts where 3 parts are for males and 2 parts are for females.
How many students are in each part?
Each part represents 1000/5 = <<1000/5=200>>200 students.
How many males are there?
So, there are 3 x 200 = <<3*200=600>>600 males.
How many females are there?
And there are 2 x 200 = <<2*200=400>>400 females.
How many males play basketball?
Hence, 600 x 2/3 = 400 males play basketball.
How many females play basketball?
And 400 x 1/5 = <<400*1/5=80>>80 females play basketball.

context: There are 15 cats in a shelter. One-third were adopted, and were replaced with twice the amount that were adopted. Later on, twice as many dogs showed up as there are cats.
main-q: How many total animals are there in the shelter?
qa-pairs: How many cats were adopted?
15/3=<<15/3=5>>5 cats were adopted out of 15.
How many cats were left?
There were 15-5 = <<15-5=10>>10 cats left.
How many more cats were added?
5*2=<<5*2=10>>10 more cats were added.
How many cats are there in the shelter?
This makes 10+10=<<10+10=20>>20 cats in the shelter.
How many dogs came into the shelter?
20*2=<<20*2=40>>40 dogs came into the shelter.
How many total animals are there in the shelter?
There are now 20+40=<<20+40=60>>60 animals in the shelter.

context: Jim decides to open up a bike shop.  The most common repair he does is fixing bike tires.  He charges $20 for this and it cost him $5 in parts.  In one month Jim does 300 of these repairs.  He also does 2 more complex repairs for $300 each and cost $50 in parts.  He also sells $2000 profit worth of things from his retail shop.
main-q: If rent and other fixed expense for the shop is $4000 a month how much profit did the shop make?
qa-pairs: How much profit did Jim make from each tire repair?
From each tire repair, he made 20-5=$<<20-5=15>>15 profit.
How much profit did Jim make from repairs?
So repairs made him a profit of 15*300=$<<15*300=4500>>4500.
How much profit did Jim make from the two complex repairs?
The two complex repairs each made him 300-50=$<<300-50=250>>250 profit.
How much profit did Jim make from the two complex repairs?
How much profit did Jim make from everything?
So his total profit from everything was 4500+500+2000=$<<4500+500+2000=7000>>7000.
How much profit did Jim make?

context: Mary went to the store to buy fruit. Apples cost $1, oranges cost $2, and bananas cost $3. For every 5 fruits that customers buy, the store offers a $1 discount. Mary buys 5 apples, 3 oranges, and 2 bananas.
main-q: How much will she pay?
qa-pairs: How much will Mary pay for apples?
For 5 apples, Mary will pay 5*1= <<5*1=5>>5 dollars.
How much will Mary pay for oranges?
For 3 oranges, she will pay 3*2= <<3*2=6>>6 dollars.
How much will Mary pay for bananas?
For 2 bananas, she will pay 2*3 = <<2*3=6>>6 dollars.
How many fruits did Mary buy?
She bought 5+3+2=<<5+3+2=10>>10 fruits.
How much of a discount does Mary get?
For 10 fruits, Mary gets a discount of 10/5 = <<10/5=2>>2 dollars.
How much will Mary pay?
In total, the bill is 5 + 6 + 6 = <<5+6+6=17>>17 dollars.

context: A school is adding 5 rows of seats to the auditorium. Each row has 8 seats and each seat costs $30. A parent, being a seat manufacturer, offered a 10% discount on each group of 10 seats purchased.
main-q: How much will the school pay for the new seats?
qa-pairs: How much do 10 seats cost?
Ten seats amount to $30 x 10 = $<<30*10=300>>300.
How much is the discount?
So there is $300 x 10/100 = $<<300*10/100=30>>30 discount for each 10 seats purchased.
How much do 10 seats cost?
Thus, the total cost for every 10 seats is $300 - $30 = $<<300-30=270>>270.
How many seats are being added?
The school is going to buy 5 x 8 = <<5*8=40>>40 seats.
How many sets of 10 seats are being bought?
This means that the school is going to buy 40/10 = <<40/10=4>>4 sets of 10 seats.
How much will the school pay for the new seats?
Therefore, the school will pay a total of $270 x 4 = $<<270*4=1080>>1080 for the new seats.

context: An office has 90 workers. 2/3rds of them are men and the rest are women. The company hires 10 new employees and 100% of them are women.
main-q: What is the total percentage of women in the company now?
qa-pairs: How many women were there before the new hires?
1/3rd of the workers before the new hires were women because 1 - (2/3) = 1/3.
How many women were there before the new hires?
There were 30 women working for the company before the new hires.
How many women are there now?
There are now 40 women working for the company because 30 + 10 = <<30+10=40>>40.
How many people are there now?
There are 100 people working for the company because 90 + 10 = <<90+10=100>>100.
What is the proportion of women working in the company now?
The proportion of women working in the company is .4 because 40 / 100 = <<40/100=.4>>.4.
What is the percentage of women working in the company now?
The percentage of women working in the company is now 40 because .4 x 100 = <<.4*100=40>>40.
